author: pwnh4
content:
Hey everyone, hope this is the appropriate channel to ask those questions:
1. Is this right: you can exit a validator by signing a `VOLUNTARY_EXIT` message with your validation key and broadcasting it to the consensus layer. Whenever a validator has finished the exit queue, it is considered withdrawable and a certain amount of withdrawals are processed at every block (with a sweep method if this is approved https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/issues/3079).
2. Where can I find information about skimming? Especially regarding the frequency of this process, will all validators of the network be skimmed at every block? Or is it a per day process? How often can the withdrawal_credentials expect to receive consensus-level rewards?
3. Can you explain the 2 CL hard forks limitation of pre-signed `VOLUNTARY_EXIT` messages (mentioned here  https://hackmd.io/@lido/BkxRxAr-o) ? Imagine an entity like lido wants its operators to exit all validators X years after their generation. Would it be safe to ask the node operators to upload a pre-signed exit message for the epoch in now + X years when they upload their deposit data to the lido contract? Or would this be inefficient as hard forks could make them invalid?
4. I have seen discussions about a dual-exit model where withdrawal_credentials would also be able to trigger the exit, especially this one https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/issues/1578, (via a similar process than how deposits work I suppose), is there anything planned for this? What would be required to start designing / implementing this?
I will be more than happy to help creating a public FAQ documentation on these topics if there is not already one available!
Thx!

author: .paulharris
content:
1> voluntary exit is an operation you can submit to the CL and it will be included in a block. There's a delay, but it is all automatic.
2> Withdrawal credentials will need to be changed to an eth1 address, which is a process that will be available in capella. once capella is up, you'll need to submit a change to update your withdrawal credentials to the new type, if it doesn't currently start with '0x01'...
Once you've done that, each block on mainnet can contain up to 16 withdrawals, they're processed from 1, so assuming everyone has a 0x01 withdrawal address you could calculate your 'worst case' to get to your validator index...

author: .paulharris
content: 3> basically a message can be signed for 'current fork' or 'next fork' so if its 2 forks in the future it won't be accepted through gossip, because signatures won't be 'valid'
